concept.title: Re-use guidelines
concept.shortdesc: Re-use guidelines can help simplify the practice of writing for re-use.

conbody.p: When writing in a DITA environment, at topic level rather than document level, there are a few guidelines you can follow to make re-use easier by adopting the following guidelines.

ul.li: Avoid the use of previous, next, earlier, and later (such as in More information on the product limitations are discussed later). Those referenced topics may not be included in all collections, or may be included in a different sequence.
Don't use sequential numbers in file names; rather, use descriptive names. (Use ej20_engine_schematic.png rather than fig1.png.)

Avoid including context within explanatory paragraphs or steps. For example, don't write The EJ20 engine of the
is naturally aspirated; rather write The EJ20 engine is naturally aspirated.

Move contextual information to its own paragraph (or context element, for task topics). In the EJ20 example preceding, the information about what models of car use the EJ20, and other information relevant to the association between EJ20 and , could be written into a separate paragraph. When the content needs to be re-used in a differently badged product manual, that context paragraph can be filtered out and the remaining non-contextual content re-used.
